verdict.summary: JSON max depth errors occur when json_decode() encounters a JSON structure nested deeper than the default 512 levels. This can indicate deeply nested API responses, recursive data structures, or malicious payloads designed to cause resource exhaustion.

dead_ends.action: Setting the depth parameter to PHP_INT_MAX
dead_ends.why_fails: Extremely deep recursion in JSON parsing can exhaust the C-level stack, causing a segfault rather than a PHP error. It also opens the application to denial-of-service attacks via crafted deeply nested JSON payloads.

dead_ends.action: Pre-processing the JSON string with regex to flatten it before decoding
dead_ends.why_fails: Regex-based JSON manipulation is inherently fragile and will break on escaped characters, unicode sequences, and edge cases. It also adds significant processing overhead for large payloads.

workarounds.action: Increase the depth parameter to a reasonable value based on expected data structure
workarounds.how: Pass a larger depth as the third argument: json_decode($json, true, 1024). Choose a value based on the known maximum nesting of your data. Values between 512 and 2048 are safe for most use cases.

workarounds.action: Validate and limit nesting depth before processing untrusted JSON
workarounds.how: For untrusted input, use a streaming JSON parser (e.g., JsonMachine) that processes tokens incrementally without building the full structure in memory. Alternatively, validate depth with a simple counter before calling json_decode().

leads_to.condition: when increasing depth limit causes large decoded arrays to consume excessive memory

preceded_by.condition: when investigating general JSON decode failures and discovering the depth limit is the specific cause

frequently_confused_with.distinction: JSON max depth is specifically error code JSON_ERROR_DEPTH, while general JSON decode errors can be syntax errors, control character issues, or malformed UTF-8
